Award.AwardTitle: Support for the Richard Tapia Celebration in Computing Conferences 2011 and 2013

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Association for Computing Machinery (ACM) proposes to support student attendance at and development of the Richard Tapia Celebration of Diversity in Computing. Tapia Conference series highlights the technical achievements of diverse researchers in computing. It provides a unique forum to support diverse students (undergraduates and graduate students) and professionals. The conference programs include invited speakers, workshops, birds-of-a-feather sessions, panels, a student poster competition and a doctorial consortium. The programs allow leadership development activities for the students as well as young professionals. Moreover, they include significant time for networking about research collaborations and professional development.
This proposal will support student scholarships for the conference and the doctoral consortium in 2011 and 2013, and partial salary for a staff person to manage the conference planning and fund raising during that period. The staff person will provide stability and consistency in correspondence with Tapia supporters, oversight for the social networking that will support communities formed at the conference, and logistical support.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The grant was used to support over 250 students for Tapia 2011, Tapia 2013, and Tapia 2014.  The breakout in terms of student support over the three Tapia Conferences are given below:

Tapia 2011:  Used to support 25 students, as the grant was awarded late in the conference planning process.  In addition the grant was used to support the Doctoral Consortium, which consisted of approximately 20 students.

Tapia 2013:  Used to support 100 students, in addition to supporting the Doctoral Consortium, which consisted of approximately 20 students.

Tapia 2014:  Used to support 90 students, which included the support for the Doctoral Consortium, which consisted of approximately 20 students.

 The results of the Tapia 2014 survey indicate the following results.  According to the survey, the top three reasons why students chose to attend Tapia were the following:

-Meet professionals in the field

-Meet recruiters for jobs, internships, post doc positions, etc.

-Encouraged by their professors to attend.

Major findings from the survey include the following:

-83% of students strongly agreed or agreed that attending Tapia increased their dedication to complete their degree.

-89% of students strongly agreed or agreed that attending Tapia reaffirmed their belief that computing was the right career for them

-99% of students strongly agreed or agreed that they were confident that they would complete their degree

The number of attendees for the Tapia conferences has grown over time, as indicated below:

Tapia 2011:  516 attendees

Tapia 2013:  550 attendees

Tapia 2014:  663 attendees

With respect to diversity, the Tapia Conference is the most diverse conference in computing.  For Tapia 2014, the 663 attendees represented:

- 47% women

- 38% African American

- 30% Hispanic/Latino

Hence, the Tapia Conference series truly impacts the increase in diversity in computing.
